class analysis.privacy_ledger.PrivacyLedger(population_size, selection_probability)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class for keeping a record of all the privacy events that occur through a DPQuery executed on a given dataset.

finalise_sample()[source]¶

Finalises sample and records sample ledger entry

get_formatted_ledger()[source]¶

Returns a formatted version of the ledger for use in privacy accounting

record_sum_query(l2_clipping_bound, noise_stddev)[source]¶

Record a query that was issued in the ledger.

Parameters

  • l2_clipping_bound – Max L2 norm of the tensor group in the query.

  • noise_stddev – The standard deviation of the noise applied to the sum.

class analysis.privacy_ledger.QueryWithLedger(query, population_size=None, selection_probability=None, ledger=None)[source]¶

Bases: pytorch_privacy.dp_query.dp_query.DPQuery

A class for DPQueries that stores the queries in a privacy ledger.

Simple wrapper for a DQQuery-PrivacyLedger pair to ensure correct running.

analysis.privacy_ledger.format_ledger(sample_array, query_array)[source]¶

Converts array representation into a list of SampleEntries.

Parameters

  • sample_array – samples are whole mechanisms applied to the data, i.e. minbatch -> grads -> clip -> sum -> noise

  • query_array – queries are the individual microbatch -> grads -> clip operations.

Composing these together is just a way of keeping a detailed record of what was done. Could be done in a flatter way I think if you were worried about simplicity. :return: A numpy + named tuple version of the TensorBuffer stored operations that have been applied to the data
